text: hello and welcome to asgl connect in today's talk we are really lucky to have chris nicholson
who's the founder of pathmind pathmind does a lot of really interesting work using deep reinforcement learning
to optimize industrial operations in chris's talk you'll see how pathmind's use of ray is
helping make deep reinforcement learning accessible to stimulation modelers with that here's chris nicholson
founder of pathmind hi michael thank you um so hi everybody thanks for joining us
looks like we have 25 people so far this is live live broadcasting to you
from alameda california so my name is chris nicholson i'm the ceo of
pathmind pathmind is a startup that applies deep reinforcement learning to an array of
industrial operations problems supply chain problems and i'm here today because we use ray
and rl lib at the core of our technology to do that so so the purpose of my talk today is
talk to talk about some practical use cases for deep rl so with that i'll share my screen
all right let me assume you can see that um now we apply deep rl to industrial
operations what does that mean exactly sorry
there we go um it means we start off in simulations
all right so a lot of you are probably familiar with um how deep reinforcement learning trains
we create uh digital replicas or our users create digital replicas of physical operations
they can do it with any logic it's a commercial simulation software they can do it with open source python
obviously that's that's ray as well um and with those replicas we can train rl
agents to learn over many runs many iterations uh the best decisions to make to
maximize or minimize overall optimize the metrics that our users care about now um working
simulations has a lot of benefits um it first of all it's low risk so these
simulations and applying rl to them these are tools of thought for people involved in maximizing throughput
minimizing costs altering physical operations is obviously a very expensive proposition so simulations is a low risk
low-cost way to explore uh what those changes would mean for their actual
systems and uh with any logic it's also highly visual meaning we can actually show
people um the the effects of how machines might move in relationship to each other if things are changed in the simulation
and that helps our users and operations managers develop an intuition of of how things would change uh in
different scenarios um but simulations are just the start so once once you've got um
a trained rl agent you can plug it into actual physical operations you can plug
it into an erp system you can plug it into a scada system and rl can act as a control tower
orchestrating the the actions of many machines at once right so it's like a coach the machines are the players
and uh those those machines are going to function best as a collective um when there's an
awareness of the whole so so we start off in simulations which are low risk and then we move to the mission critical
right where we're making real decisions and feeding them into um operational systems in the world so
there are many fields of application uh for this kind of optimization we happen to focus on
industrial control factories and warehouses um warehouses and factories are obviously
also part of supply chains so you'll hear people talk about industrial ops you'll hear them talk about supply chain
really those are two sides of the same coin you start inside the walls you move out but you you face a lot of the same
scheduling and cueing problems uh all up and down that chain um then finally you've got energy
management responding to say electricity prices on the grid these are there there's an array of problems that
reinforcement learning is great at optimizing for and i'm going to get into some of those use cases down below
sorry a little feedback there um but what i'd like to point out is that um the way these systems are
optimized now is often brittle all right so a lot of people are taking an approach that may be based on linear programming
or a mathematical solver and those optimizers will break when data
variability gets very big when they when they confront situations that they didn't solve initially and when those
optimizers break it causes a lot of waste right so so current optimization systems are brittle and wasteful and one of the
reasons uh why they're brittle and wasteful is because oftentimes the if you're in a multi-agent scenario
it's very hard to make those machines respond to each other it's very hard to write a heuristic that directs the actions of those
machines so that they act in concert to serve a larger goal as
opposed to maximizing uh individual rewards
so at the core of the problem that people face in industrial operations and supply
chain is what we call data variability it really means a lot of the events that
uh a lot of the events that we've all experienced over the last year right running out of uh toilet paper
in american supermarkets in in march for example like that that's a a wonderful and sad
example of data variability unexpected things happen right they happen all the time they happen in physical operations
right machines break down suppliers evaporate demand can go down or it can go through
the roof as it did for a lot of e-commerce e-commerce companies this year and that data variability
um needs to be responded to right physical operations uh don't have any
choice but to respond to that variability if they do it poorly the stakes are high and they can go out of business so so
what we're proposing to people is rl as a foundation of the predictive
models that are both adaptive and responsive to that data variability and one reason why it's more
adaptive to that variability is because simulations allow us to train and to experience um many
realities that that are not out there in the world now right they simply allow us to to
build an intuition about how to act in things that maybe nobody's ever seen before but that could be coming down the pike
and that's that's crucial in supply chains because um we've seen our supply chains uh break
down over the last 12 months we've seen those supply chains lack transparency we've seen
enormous bottlenecks occur and being able to look upstream and
downstream and do things like capacity planning and production planning are crucial and those are the those are
the types of decisions that that rl can help people make um so
pathmind essentially takes these simulations it outputs a predictive model or an rl policy
um and there there are essentially three value propositions one um it's more accurate right so so it
can increase performance period uh two uh it can continue to
work in systems where data has changed a great deal so it's adaptive and another way of
saying that is that we can maintain the turnaround or a relatively low latency without having to recalculate a solver
even in the face of changing data and in three we can solve previously unsolvable
problems right uh and by that i mean we can optimize net new situations where you've got
many agents multiple objectives so so several goals say i want to maximize throughput
minimize cost minimize my carbon footprint in a complex scenario that's actually really hard to write a
heuristic for which is it's hard it's hard to optimize for with a solver um but rl through trial and error can
actually find ways to do that um so so those are the situations where this kind of optimization is actually
giving people an advantage over what they were doing before um and when i say it's giving them an advantage um
you know just like deepmind beat the world champions and go a few
years ago and rather unexpectedly or ahead of schedule and just like we've seen them do
they and open ai do really amazing things um with with deep reinforcement learning
games many that that same um that same difference that that same improvement in
performance is actually possible in a lot of real world situations um so we're consistently seeing uh double
digits so 10 are above the improvements on use case after use case especially the closer those uh closer
a situation is to real life that is to say the more pertinent it did pertinent it is to actual operations um
the better rl is going to do against any other optimizer
um so another aspect of this uh is that rrl as many of the people
on this call know rl is a tricky beast to tune right um now ray does a lot to make that
ray and rlib do a lot to make that easier but not everybody knows the right rl architecture to choose not everybody
knows the right hyper parameters to tune for um and and
that iterative process can can be long and difficult now um one thing that pathmind has done is
we've basically made reinforcement learning accessible to the simulation modelers of the world the simulation modelers of the world are not
necessarily trained data scientists they're not necessarily trained to set up and maintain a distributed
cluster in the cloud what they are is people with domain knowledge
who know how to build a simulation and what we what we allow them to do is load those simulations up uh choose
their observations so what they kind of what they're grabbing from state uh choose the actions that they want to
inject back into the environment um and write the reward functions
but those reward functions can be relatively simple and due to some stuff that pathmind does on the back end
we can we can get them to results quickly even if the rewards are what what many
people would consider sparse so where is this being applied let's
talk about some concrete use cases uh pathmind is working with a number of
global engineering consultancies to get this technology into real operations around the world
one example there's a metals processor um they're they're taking metal ore they're
putting it into that's for electrolysis into a solution they're running electricity through the solution
um and separating the metal from the rest now electricity is one of the main
ingredients in that process um and it so happens and all of us probably have personal experience of it
that electricity prices can change um and in the case of this metals processing plant they're watching
electricity prices double in the space of an hour right so for a business that needs to have predictable expenses
and meet its quota no matter what the electricity prices are um being able to respond
to those prices and to know when it can when it can ramp down its electrolysis vats and still meet its
quota is is the use case right so so it's it's about um making predictions about where prices
are going to go reading subtle price signals and then making decisions about what the factory should do
given the logic baked into the simulation about how those electrolysis fats
can can be modified um or how we can ramp them up and wrap them down then finally beyond that plants like
this and really factories around the world are moving towards renewables wherever they can um and renewables
have their own variants obviously based on the weather and based on daylight or wind and so
so based on the the prices coming off the grid they may make a decision to swap their
power source over to solar at certain points um instead of ramping down
that so so what so path mines in a pilot where we're taking real data um
we're next to the legacy system and we're showing them how they can achieve more than a 10 reduction um in their
electricity costs right and for for a lot of factories a 10 reduction first of all is almost unheard
of and second of all um adds up to millions of dollars a year so i'd like to talk about a couple other
examples here um now basically the key idea to a lot of
industrial operations and supply chain problems is simply throughput
how do i get things from the source to the destination as quickly and efficiently as possible
on how do i minimize late delivery later late deliveries because when things are
late sometimes they're no longer profitable depending on the guarantees you've given the customer
so what pathmind is able to do is say take a simulation you can see it in the lower left-hand side
of several sources of goods say factories um running goods through several warehouses based
on the orders those where warehouses are receiving from uh downstream in the supply chain to
minimize the number of late deliveries and thereby maximize profitability so here again um this is the use case where
we've we've built the models we're working with teams of simulation engineers helping with things like product delivery
and seeing these double-digit gains that's not i'll make a brief digression
that's not the only um use case in warehouses warehouses are a really interesting place actually
they've got a ton of optimization problems to solve every single one of them operates like
almost like a maritime port right you've got a ton of trucks coming into the loading docks
those trucks need to be scheduled where they're going to land they need to be unloaded and then and then they need to be
reloaded with goods to to take elsewhere and so that entire process of scheduling
matching those trucks with the right resources they could be machines or labor and then moving those goods to the right
spot on the racks so that it can be quickly moved out of the warehouse house later
that's a series of optimization problems and every warehouse in the world confronts that many of them are not as
nearly as optimized as as they should be but several i'd say global warehouse operators
are working on those problems now and amazon's a perfect example but they're not the only ones
so another problem and this is really a multi-billion dollar problem in the world right now is
um the supply chain visibility and supply chain optimization so that's my current slide um
you've got you got these these choke points up and down the system
that are based on not just a lack of transparency but bad data so the way to think about a
supply chain is it's a it's a flow of goods money and information right um and the
information is is what we care about now right so a lot of these stations in the supply chain
are not sharing information well and when they do share that information well they're not processing well so they're not making the right decisions
um based on the capacity of their partners to place orders at the right time
one thing pathmind can do given good information is help
organizations downstream send orders upstream so that they get just the right amount
of inventory right just enough inventory so to speak so more inventory is not always better
there are obviously costs of carrying inventory but leaving money on the table when you get an order can't fill it is also bad so there's a
there's a narrow middle road to take right and being on that narrow road is is the goal of this kind of optimization
um another problem that we've been able to help people solve is is what we call the product delivery
or the rooting problem so the rooting problem really gets into
not just fast deliveries but also minimizing carbon footprints right so another aspect of the changes
that factories warehouses and supply chains are undergoing today and and believe me there are enormous
transformations not just due to coded but say in the automotive industry due to electric vehicles
and um and avs um there's enormous changes going on and one of the changes and it's really a
top-down mandate is these companies are required to reduce their carbon footprint
so what does that mean exactly well that can mean that they they have more objectives now it's a multi-objective
problem right so they're used to trying to solve for um uh faster deliveries uh more
throughput and cost minimization and all of a sudden they need to take into account this
other thing how do i do all of that and minimize the amount of fuel or vehicles that i'm using
right and the way the way reinforcement learning
works is that it's actually fairly simple to add new variables to a reward
function alter the simulation and find uh find the new best decisions uh
based on the new incentives uh or the or the the shifts in the environment that you as an actor face
um so finally i'll talk a little bit about factories and crane models um so

and simply by basing decisions on on observations about the capacity of

uh operating all around your agent

break the legacy systems but because we can train because we can
